title: Justinianic Plague
description: A bubonic plague pandemic that struck the Byzantine Empire and Mediterranean, killing an estimated 25–50 million people and weakening Roman-era states.

title: Black Death
description: One of the deadliest pandemics in human history (bubonic plague), estimated to have killed 30–60% of Europe's population and reshaped European economics, society, and culture.

title: Old World–New World Epidemics
description: The Columbian Exchange introduced smallpox, measles, and other diseases to the Americas, causing catastrophic population declines among Indigenous peoples.

title: Spanish Flu (H1N1)
description: Influenza pandemic that infected a third of the global population and caused tens of millions of deaths; notable for high mortality in young adults.

title: HIV/AIDS Pandemic
description: Identified in the early 1980s, HIV/AIDS has caused millions of deaths worldwide and led to major advances in virology, medicine, and public health responses.

title: SARS
description: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome emerged in China and spread internationally, causing concern but ultimately contained through public health measures.

title: H1N1 (Swine Flu)
description: A global influenza outbreak declared a pandemic in 2009; generally milder than 1918 but still caused significant morbidity and mortality.

title: West African Ebola Epidemic
description: Largest Ebola outbreak in history, causing widespread fatalities and international public health response in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone.

title: COVID-19 Pandemic
description: Global pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2 leading to widespread health, economic, and social disruption; spurred vaccine development and public health innovations.
